evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew withstands alternative interpretations and contradicting evidence within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim, such as timing, involved personnel, and situational context.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The observed lack of warnings and insufficient signals imply communication/coordination breakdown
The dataset's historical records accurately reflect crew interactions
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures better explained the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication and coordination among crew and support that breakdown occurred, with H8 highlighting insufficient signaling and lack of warnings, supporting the claim of observable communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim context is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim period.

assumptions: No mechanical failure was reported or observed in the evidence; the continued movement beyond TRP was due to procedural or human factors.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical or control system faults or failures during the pushback, this would support mechanical/control failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircrafts nosewheel reached the Tug release point (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8) indicates no mechanical or control failure was reported; the issue was related to procedural and communication factors during pushback, favoring procedural deviation over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit mechanical failure reports; ambiguity in cause of continued movement beyond TRP.
